page.title: 03FINGRINGHOE RANGES
page.content: A large area of land near the river {Colne}is covered by{Fingringhoe {Ranges.}We went up a control tower where we saw the sea, some fields and some tractors cutting for silage. There are quite a few drains because the land slopes gently. Near South House Farm the land is 50ft. People cut the fields for silage and drain it so animals can graze. In the camp they bring up baby wild ducks (mallard) from a day old until they are ready to fend for themselves. If a species of bird has been depleted by a bad winter,the camp superintendant rears birds to top up stocks in the wild.They work with the department of the environment.The ranges there were first built by the Americans after the war.The army still uses Fingringhoe for a shooting range.
